Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Snyder did an outstanding job of not only teaching the historical events that occurred, but also developing intellectual frameworks about the underlying motivations of people and their leaders during these transformative events.

HIST 264 is a whirlwind tour through the history of Eastern Europe since the beginning of WWI.  Throughout the course I expanded my base of knowledge about an area of the world that is largely ignored in the teaching of European history in the United States.

I gained an incredible amount of insight about the history of Eastern Europe since 1914, with specific knowledge gained about WWII and its effects of Eastern Europe and the rise and fall of communism in Eastern Europe. Having never really learned in depth about this History of Eastern Europe, this class was incredibly interesting and had lots of relevant and fascinating (and often saddening) information.
Great overview of history, you learn a lot of stuff that you really can't learn anywhere else.
History.

I learned a lot about WWI and WWII and the repercussions for Eastern European countries after those events. I realized how inadequate AP World History and AP US History was in covering these two important events that really shaped the current landscape of the Europe that we know today.

This is an amazing course! Whether you are a history major or not, this is a must-take course that isn't incredibly difficult but you learn a lot. Professor Snyder's lectures were one of the highlights of my week, and just by listening to his lectures, you learn a ton.

I learned SO much about Eastern Europe after 1914 - most importantly, the fall of Communism and WWII. This course also really taught me about how fragile world systems are - that the way the world is now/the dominant forces we have come to know have arisen so much more recently than we think, and, moreover, were never inevitable. Professor Snyder also fundamentally changed my view regarding the relationship of history and memory/the relationship of past to the present. Overall, I feel like I have gained knowledge of incredibly important events in 20th century European history and how these events, in turn, paved the way for current developments. The lectures on the Holocaust and WWII especially blew my mind - so much of what I thought I knew turned out to be totally incorrect. I have learned more engaging and relevant material - at a relatively low cost - in HIST 264 than in any other class at Yale. The ratio of work put it/amount gained is really incredible - the course isn't particularly demanding, but will fundamentally change your view of the past, present, and future.
I learned about the history of Eastern Europe from WWI to present day

I gained a more holistic understand of the origins of conflict in Eastern Europe and particularly, how it developed the post-Communist character that many nations display today. The material was incredibly eye-opening.
Lots of info about history, Eastern Europe, and the mindset of the past century.
I learned a lot about the countries of Eastern Europe. The class covers the advertised material extensively.

Definitely delved deeper into lesser-known aspects of the history of Eastern Europe. I was able to develop a more comprehensive understanding of the post-World War I order, the interwar period, and World War II. My perception of the Holocaust was altered as well; it's easy to think that the atrocities were carried out by "evil people," and that we as humans have somehow advanced to a point where we are no longer capable of those same horrific acts. This course really hammered home the point that the Holocaust required the conscious cooperation of many of the people in Nazi-occupied countries, and that there truly were very few people willing and able to resist the Nazi extermination of Jews when the economic and political conditions of the time made it advantageous to simply cooperate. Furthermore, I was able to develop a much more nuanced understanding of the complex history of Communism in Eastern Europe. The fall of Communism was not quite as inevitable as it is sometimes made out to be, and the dichotomy of capitalism/democracy=good and Communism=bad doesn't quite capture the intricacies of its rise and fall. I most certainly developed a deeper appreciation for this part of the world, and on a more general level, the lessons that history can continue to offer us for the present and the future.
Understanding of Eastern European history from WWI onward. Knowledge of communist system, Cold War dynamics, Eastern European culture, etc.
Very interesting content, learned a lot about a region of the world that is often left out of discussions about history, especially during this time period.
I have developed a basic understanding of the common themes that drove the history of eastern europe since 1914.

This was a great overview of the history of Eastern Europe beginning with WWI. It is such an important region where so many important historical events occurred but often gets overlooked in favor of Western Europe. It gave me a completely new side to the story of both World Wars and the Cold War.
History lol.
I learned a lot about Eastern Europe!
Thinking about history in a more psychological manner.
I learned how to better understand the history of the many countries of Europe, given the context of the history of the region.

I learned how to look at the innumerable different historical events and factors of Eastern European history after WWI in terms of the broader contexts and outlines laid out in lectures. I learned how to process and retain large amounts of information at a time in a short period of time.
A much better understanding of the region as a whole.

This course teaches you a lot about the interwar and post-war period in Eastern Europe, about the political, economic and social implications of the post-war treaties, the rise of communism and the different political systems.
Lots of knowledge and philosophy from Eastern Europe
Learned a lot about Eastern Europe, the development of states, and the patterns of Communism

I learned how to understand history from an analytical perspective through models that I've not understood before. I think that history as a discipline allows me to understand deeply how the past can connect to the present with its similar underpinnings in certain historical events or triggers of those historical events. I also learned a lot of facts that as Professor Snyder says, will be useful in my bourgeois life in the society in the future. It was a great course.

Broad overview of Eastern European history and historiography from 1914; interrelation between the big events of the 20th century (WWI, depression, WWII, Cold War), nationalism,  fascism, and communism as ideologies.
Learned so much about Eastern europe

We learned about the Eastern European region in the 20th century, covering the post world war 1 period, the fall of democracy, the second world war, the rise of communism, and the fall of communism.  All in all a pretty comprehensive course.
Never have I felt like I have learned so much in such a short period of time. Professor Snyder packs in so much but does so thoughtfully and gracefully. Truly an amazing course.

The course provides a great background on modern Eastern European history while touching on major themes and tensions such as nationalism and ethnicity and how they impact state formation not only in the time period of study but understanding how that translates into modern day issues.
Developed a strong understanding of Eastern/Central Europe Politics, Events, and Trends.
A fresh conceptual framework to understand the history of Eastern Europe.

I definitely feel like I gained a very solid understanding of the basic modern history of Eastern Europe, as well as exploring some of the broader historical themes and trends in the region and beyond. Id say that unless you really do all the readings, the level of understanding can feel a bit cursory, but even if all you do is attend the lectures youll hear some great stories and learn a decent amountespecially about Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia, and in particular Poland, Snyders favorites.
I learnt a lot about Eastern Europe, particularly the Balkan nations that are so often overlooked in other history courses.

I became better at reading translated sources (most of the reading from the course were dense because they were translated from Eastern European languages). I also learned how to look at broad trends in history, especially with how states fail and how new governments seize power.

This is a really insightful course which gives you a great background about the history of Eastern Europe. You learn about all the political systems stretching from fascism to socialism to communism, which is relevant to the world we live in today. The course takes you all to modern day Europe, which connects the events of the past century.
Learnt to identify historical themes across long periods of time and across many countries

Just as in last semester, I learned so much from Professor Snyder in his Eastern European history lecture. I learned a lot about the history of the region, but also about what makes a good historian, and how the history of Eastern Europe is relevant to our current political situation.

I learned a ton about the events, trends, cultures, and major players of Eastern European history. I feel like I learned so much about how to analyze historical events and to place them within larger historical trends. I feel like this class not only taught me about the history of Eastern Europe, but about democracy, society, and major political concepts in general.

I developed a much better understanding of contemporary Eastern European history with this course and greatly appreciated the emphasis given towards connecting all of the events through general themes regarding the importance of history and its relationship with memory. This class taught me to think in broad terms about an extensive period of time without sacrificing the specific details which would substantiate my arguments.

Take important notes while
Person speaks
A very high-level understanding of the major events in Eastern European history between about 1914 and the fall of Communism.

This course taught me about the complexities and challenges facing the region of Eastern Europe. I learned how to analyze sources and to try and seek explanations on not only why things happened, but also how they were and are remembered and are stitched into the history books.

I was exposed to a section of European history I had never explored before. I learned how different political structures in Eastern Europe developed during this time period and how the countries of Eastern Europe interacted with the West and each other. This provided insight into origins of political systems that are now in place in Eastern Europe.
Learned about trends in history in Eastern Europe in the 20th century, how balances of power shifted, how nation-states came together and evolved and sovereignties changed.

I learned a lot about the history of Eastern Europe and how certain developments led to the events that took place. But more importantly, and interestingly, the course taught us to compare developments in various countries and analyse the differences and similarities and use these to make claims about the "bigger picture."
Would have been nice to have fewer Marci Shore guest lectures.
The lectures are very informative and interesting! However the grading is super dependent on your TA and can vary wildly, so watch out for that.

The course's biggest strength is the professor.  Professor Snyder is an absolute treasure, and is one of the finest historical scholars of his generation.  It was an absolute privilege being able to listen to him speak twice a week this semester.

As is frequently the case with history courses, this class's biggest weakness was section.  I did not find that it added very much to my experience in the class, and would have preferred to have not had a section at all.

The strengths of this course are that it provides an incredible amount of information and detail about the inner workings of Eastern Europe since 1914. The course was incredibly engaging and despite having no visual presentation, Professor Snyder created an incredibly interesting and engaging class environment. I know that no computers is an incredibly important rule to the class, so perhaps more detailed terms sheets would be helpful because sometimes it was hard to get down all of the necessary notes because of the large amount of information shared at every lecture.
The reading felt a little heavy at times, but it's history so what can you do.
The fact you're letting Schnyder leave on sabbatical is, to a degree, ridiculous. Stop letting the history department erode; I don't want to fall into the sea of economics majors.

The lectures were generally pretty good. Other than the one lecture about the origins of Lenin in Russia, the lectures from Marci Shore were pretty dry. They didn't really have that much content; they were filled with mostly anecdotes and it was difficult seeing how that fit into the larger picture. There were too many readings and they were often times very difficult to follow, especially for someone with little prior knowledge about the history of the region. Also, it would be nice if Professor Snyder used Canvas to communicate with us if he was going to switch up lectures. I think the class should have a more realistic expectation of what readings can be done each week. 200 pages per week is probably too much.

The course's greatest strength are the incredible lectures by Tim Sydner (and often his wife, Marci Shore). Professor Snyder is a marvelous speaker who knows so much and delivers this knowledge with incredible panache and delightfully dry humor. It is an amazing opportunity to be able to take a class from someone who is truly such a renowned expert in their field. His lectures are consistently enlightening, fascinating, and hilarious - HIST 264 is perhaps my only lecture at Yale in which the time seems to fly by. Professor Snyder doesn't really care about the students and is incredibly far removed, but I wouldn't even count this as a weakness: showing up to hear him speak is basically what the course is about, and a gift in-and-of itself. There are a good amount of readings assigned but you honestly do not need to do them. All that is truly required is taking good notes and really understanding what Professor Snyder talks about in class. I would, however, recommend reading the books he wrote himself. Section is very important - your TA can make or break your performance in the class and engagement with the material. I was lucky to have a wonderful TA who seriously made sure we were keeping up and understanding the big themes at very step of the course. The exams are also easy - you have plenty of time, and are always given ample choice of essay questions and IDs. As Professor Snyder is so disengaged, the TAs have a lot of freedom - it is thus very important to know what your TA expects from you on the exams and the course in general. The only true weakness of the course is that it seems like Professor Snyder hasn't looked at the syllabus since 2005 and has never once used any technology - all information about exams, etc. thus comes in brief, often unclear announcements during class. It can thus be very confusing about what is going on re: exams - such as what readings will be on the test, etc. Often, each of the TAs will tell their sections entirely different things. Overall, however, this is the one flaw in an extraordinary - and extraordinarily accessible - course.

Strengths: Engaged TAs!
Weaknesses: The note sheet outlines often ran out before I got to class (I had a class on science hill right before)- would have been nice to have pdfs uploaded to canvas!

It is not fair that some TAs tell their sections exactly what to study and what will be on the exam, while others give little guidance. Some TAs grade much more harshly than others. Solution: the professor should simply not tell TAs in advance what the test will be. Marci Shore was a very good substitute, however it was totally clear she and Tim never discussed what she should teach us and she always has to ask what we already knew. If he needs Prof Shore to sub for him, she should be properly briefed on what to lecture.

It's a fantastic course, with interesting readings and enjoyable lectures. 
The structure of the overall course was great. 

It would be nice if the lectures had a bit more structure individually. They don't go chronologically or by country and have a lot of "oh-by-the-way"s thrown in, so it's very hard to take coherent notes.
The course was fantastic at engaging students, mostly because Professor Snyder is an excellent lecturer. His wife Marci Shore is also superb at narrating history in a palatable way.
It's a great class. The lectures were so good that not once over the course of the semester did I think about skipping them

The course material itself is fascinating, and the reading supplements the lectures and topics of interest in the course very well (although I did sometimes feel that the amount we had to read was excessive.) A significant weakness of the class was its lack of existence online: the outline sheets for the lectures would often run out, and there was no way to access the sheets elsewhere. Simply uploading these outlines online would make running out of them during lecture less of a hassle, and would also facilitate greater convenience in studying. On a final note, I did hear mention of different grading criteria/expectations from different TA's, and I feel that unified, rigorous standards across the board would be more fair for all students taking the class.
Probably the best class I have taken at Yale, except maybe for Snyder's HIST 263 last semester. He is an unparalleled lecturer and my TA, Karolina Kolpak, is a fantastic educator and scholar.

There is a lot of stuff thrown at you all at once. I think the reading load was way too heavy and the lectures too short. Tim Snyder is a fantastic professor, but it often felt like we were cramming way too much information into each class. It could be better organized.
Sections is a pain  don't really add to the class.
Perhaps finding a way to avoid grade deflation in this class.

Professor Snyder is an excellent lecturer and makes the course extremely interesting and engaging. I also really liked the way he organized assessments (1 midterm, 1 final, 2 quizzes). I would have appreciated some sort of online resource to reference as sometimes he goes very fast and details are skimmed over quickly.

In general, this course is legendary for a reason. Professor Snyder is everything he is cracked up to behe will engage you to the highest level in thinking about Eastern Europe, statehood, ideology, and history as discipline. Everyone should take this course.

Any weakness lie in the organization of this course, which simply needs to be better. The TFs were consistently giving outdifferent information, and at different times. The pipeline of information about tests needs to be significantly improved there just needs to be an official message about what is happening that is given to everybody, instead of weird clues given independently by different TFs. Also, there is sometimes just way too much reading. The last week of classes had, and this is NOT an exaggeration, 700 pages of reading. No one is going to read all of that, I'm sorry. (but if you cut something, please don't cut Marci Shore's book! it was so good!) These are small things, and can easily be adjusted. In general, this course is incredible.

Worth the hype everyone should take the course. I learned SO much. There are enough reviews saying this that this should be pretty clear.

Weaknesses  the TFs were not organized at all in terms of information about tests. This seriously needs to be better in the future, because this semester every TF would give some different idea about what the test would be, which is not helpful. The pipeline of info should be clear and unified. 

Also, sometimes there is too much reading. There should not have been literally 700 pages of reading the last week of classes. No one is going to do that, I'm sorry. (but Marci Shore's book was SO GOOD so please don't cut that)
Interesting. So date oriented. Why make us memorize a million dates and not even tell us which ones.
Very interesting lectures, good section. Lots of readings which can be dense and difficult to get through.

The material is fascinating, the readings are for the most part good and related to course material (especially the Snyder and Shore readings) and the lectures are wonderful.
Professor Snyder is a great lecturer, but an extremely inaccessible teacher--he has not responded to a single query directed to him by myself or my friends. Additionally, it was very difficult to figure out what would be on the tests. Prof Snyder doesn't use Canvas much, so he just says what will be on the test in class, and frequently that information is wrong. This class would be a perfect course if Professor Snyder would just send a clear list of what would be covered on the test via Canvas.
Fewer readings would be better.
The strengths are professor Snyder's unbelievable lecturing and engagement, as well as the diverse readings which supplement the lectures perfectly.

One strength is how Professor Snyder condensed such large and detailed topics into bigger picture ideas. I also loved Marci Shores guest lectures. One weakness is figuring out how to incorporate all the readings into my learning process if we didnt touch on them in lecture or section.

I thought it was very interesting and I enjoyed it much more than I thought I was going to. I felt like it was really structured to help learn how the timeline of history is connected and builds on itself. I learned way more about why the events were happening.
Professor Snyder is a great professor, the lectures were well-structured and the exams were fair. The readings were interesting but were quite long and extensive!

This course delivers a lot of information in a very short period of time.  You'll learn a lot, and the more reading you do, the more you'll learn

A lot of the reading from secondary sources in the course packet tends to be very, very dry.  Focusing on primary sources will probably be better for your sanity

The lectures are superb. The handouts are helpful without being distracting, and the lectures have theses that are clear and insightful. Somehow, even though lectures feel free form, they NEVER run over or seem rushed. I find this very impressive especially given my experiences otherwise in lectures at Yale. The readings are interesting, but super heavy. I do wish the lecture handouts were available online.

Lectures were amazing -- hands-down one of the best that I've had at Yale. Professor Snyder is truly one of a kind and his traditional method of lecture, 50 minutes of very well-organized, thought-provoking bits of history will leave you in awe after every single one of it.
Snyder is an extraordinary lecturer but the course was at times disorganized (for example, TFs fluctuated wildly during first two weeks, plan for a midterm review session fell through)
Professor snyder is the greatest lecturer

The lectures were great, I would recommend making it a point not to skip any if you can, not because it'll be possible to pass the class, but because Professor Snyder is a pretty good storyteller who can carry an engaging narrative throughout the semester.  I felt like there were too many readings, however.  I'm a STEM kid, so I wasn't used to dealing with 150+ pages of readings per week.  It wasn't the quantity though, it just felt like every week there would be readings that were clearly less important than others.  Some system of starring the important readings would be useful.

I think the course was very well sequenced and did a great job of hitting all of the major events/places. I learned so much. It was sometimes hard to follow, however, because Professor Snyder talks very fast. It was also very disorganized. The TAs all seemed to think/teach different things about assignments.
Professor Snyder's lectures were some of the best at Yale. He has an uncanny ability to relay a full historical account while remaining engaging and insightful.
Lectures from Tim Snyder were fantastic and so were guest lectures from Marci Shore
Slow down in lecture for gods sake
Prof Snyder is an excellent lecturer

Lectures are fantastic. Appreciate the no-tech policy. Biggest complaint is that the readings, while actually pretty engaging and interesting, are assigned in such volume that it often felt too daunting to do any of them at all. I think if the volume were reduced a bit, everyone might actually do more reading.
Reading quantity can be a bit overwhelming at times.

I think section could have been more helpful. While discussing the readings was engaging, I think using section as a way to reinforce and clarify the events of E European history would be more beneficial to the class. However, I found going to lecture to be really great; Professor Snyder is a great speaker and always was able to draw a big picture idea out of the specific events of a topic.

Professor Snyder is amazing and is the best historian in his field. He knows so much and I loved his teaching style which was very entertaining. He covers a reasonable amount of content during lectures. His wife also gave a few lectures which were really great!

The lectures were brilliant and stimulating. Some of the readings were a little dense or unnecessary such as the number of books we were made to buy and then read last minute at the end, as if they were an afterthought. 
Professor Snyder was very good at tying all the informatio together but without him it would be easy to get lost amogst all the material.

The course's main strength are the fabulous lectures. The main weakness would be the level of reading. I think that sometimes the quantity of material assigned is a little unrealistic, with several hundred pages being assigned for a lecture course. Sections were also great.

Strengths - extremely interesting lectures, great discussion sections

Weaknesses - occasionally, readings could be a bit too long/confusing, but in general were good
Not helpful when studying for exams

Tim Snyder is well known for being a talented lecturer, which indeed he is. He is also recognized as an authority on Eastern European history. But while the lecture itself is fascinating, the logistics of the course could use substantial improvement in two areas. Specifically: 1) Expectations for exams were never clear, especially for the map quiz, midterm, and Communist Terminology Test (the expectations for the final were a bit clearer, since he told us it would be just like the midterm, which it was). My TA got 70 emails asking about the map quiz, which was not surprising at all, considering that nothing was posted on Canvas and the description of the quiz given in class was extremely vague. I think that 70 emails are a clear indication that something is wrong. Expectations for the quizzes and tests should be more clearly specified, and they should be posted on Canvas, since they are addressed so quickly in class. 2) Readings for the class were way too much, usually 200-400 very dense pages per week. You just cant expect that out of undergrads, who average 4.5 classes per semester: thats 900-1800 pages a week, which is pretty ridiculous. As a result, nobody actually did all the readings (or even a big portion of them), which made section pretty bad. If less reading was assigned, I would try and actually do it, but with this much its just unrealistic.

This course does a great job of immersing the students within Eastern Europe, bringing to light the different challenges faced by so many people. The readings which accompanied this class were insightful and fantastic.
I wish Professor Snyder would lecture more often and not have as many guest lectures. Professor Shores lectures were not as strong I found.

This course focused on the history of Eastern Europe as a whole rather than exploring the histories of its nations separately which helped prevent nationalist bias. This approach, however, excluded the histories of some Eastern European countries, such as the Baltic states, which did not seem to figure as much into the regional history.
Strengths: Prof Snyder is an engaging lecturer.

In my opinion, this course was amazing and did not have any significant weaknesses. The professor was engaging, funny, and skilled at lecturing, which made attending class a joy. The TAs were very competent and helpful and led interesting discussion sections. The readings, although heavy at times, were very insightful and essential to the understanding of the course.
Absolutely
Yes! It is a great survey course for Eastern European history.
Snyder is the absolute best Professor I've ever had. You. Must. Take. This. Class.

Take this class!  This is a "must-take" course along with a few others in the history department.  Professor Snyder is one of the finest historians currently alive, and you would be doing yourself a disservice by not taking this class.

I would recommend this course to another student because it was incredible interesting, engaging, and informative. Eastern Europe since 1914 was recommended to me as one of the courses I had to take while at Yale for these reasons, and I would absolutely tell (and already have told) other people to take it.

You've just gotta take it. Snyder is the best - it's like listening to a podcast every day. The material is fascinating and the grading was easy. There's a lot of assigned reading but you don't have to do all of it to do well. Just pick out the most important ones to read and listen thoughtfully in lecture.
If Tim Schnyder is teaching it, yes. I can't recommend this class without a professor I know.

This is a good course to take if you want a better understanding of the history that led to the current state of affairs in Europe today. If you only do a few of all the readings, you should be fine; most of the tests come from lectures, and if your TA is good, you should be able to get the key details from the reading in section.
Absolutely.
Great history lecture course. Snyder knows how to tell a story, and it shines through each lecture. Readings are not necessary as long as you go to class and pay attention. Great fifth class!

Absolutely! I could not recommend this course enough. HIST 264 will fundamentally change your view of history, and how history bleeds into the present. Moreover, I feel that now I finally understand some of the most important events in recent history: WWII and the fall of Communism. Moreover, the class is incredibly accessible. The exams are easy and do not require heavy conceptual lifting - just a firm grasp of the material presented in lecture. You truly do not have to be a history major - or even interested in history at all - to take this course. If someone was going to take only one history course in their time at Yale, I would say they should take this one. I have already recommended the course to all of my friends.
It's okay. You could probably get everything you needed from reading Snyder and Shore's books.
Frankly, I was taking this class CR/D, so my engagement was relatively low, but I wish that I'd actually taken it for a grade, since I ended up really enjoying it and learning a lot!
Grading was extremely uneven across sections. However, Snyder is a brilliant lecturer and academic whose historical interpretations encompass the political economy and span up to present day.

Yesit's a fascinating period of history, the workload is not really demanding (map quiz, midterm, communist terminology quiz, final, and section participation). You will learn a lot and Professor Snyder is a fantastic lecturer.

I recommend this course. 
It makes clear a lot of the important events of the past century and gives you some insights into their connection with current events. When I first stopped it I thought, how does Easter Europe concern me. But it's bigger than Eastern Europe. Take it.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student who has even an inkling of interest about Eastern European political character. It was not too much work--a doable amount of reading, and I gained so much from it.
Yes!

Yes, most definitely. You will develop a more nuanced understanding of some of the most momentous events of the 20th Century, and learn to examine events with more of a critical eye instead of accepting the simplified, ideologically convenient, black-and-white narrative.
Wholeheartedly
Yes, but be prepared to teach yourself most of the material.

If you are in for some mindblowing lectures and just genuinely unparalleled public speaking skills, take this class! But otherwise really not what it's hyped up to be. I wish the class covered less material but in more details. We ended up repeating historic stereotypes a lot. If you do take this class, make sure to do the readings before each lecture. Your level of commitment really matters in getting a good experience.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in history/Eastern Europe, or just looking for a great lecture!

The course is legendary for a reason, and every Yale student should take it. You will not stop writing during every lecture, because there is so many good things to write down. This is also a great class to take as your first or only history class, as Prof. Snyder does a good job engaging at a high level without being esoteric also, there are no papers but only tests (midterm, non-cumulative final, and two quizzes). In general, I did not find the grading to be that difficult, although that could have just been my TF.

Take this course, everyone! It is totally worth the hype. 

It's also not that hard  midterm, non-cumulative final, section participation, and two quizzes make up the entire grade. The reading is good but you don't really need to do all of it. If you have to choose, definitely read Prof. Snyder and Prof. Shore's books, as they are very engaging.
No. Waste of time memorizing dates
Yes, Timothy Snyder is probably one of the best lecturers at Yale. I looked forward to class every tuesday and thursday.
Yes! I learned a lot and had a wonderful time in lecture.
Yes! Professor Snyder is a must.
Of course. It's taught by Timothy Snyder.
Yes

Yes, the readings look overwhelming but if you read what is interesting to you, you can do pretty well in the class. The course is structured in a way where you can focus on the things that are the most interesting to you if you want.

This course is really interesting and Professor Snyder is an amazing lecturer! The course spans over the interwar and post-war periods and will teach you a lot about a really intricate part of Europe. Even if you're not a History major, and especially if you like taking exams instead of writing research papers, this class is great. The lectures are captivating, the readings are quite extensive but the exams only test you on IDs, dates and a short essay. Would definitely recommend to anyone who wants an interesting and easy history class!
One of the best history classes at Yale. Take anything offered by Snyder. You wont regret it.
Highly.  Snyder is the most engaging lecturer I've ever had, and the material is highly interesting
Yes! Its a lot of reading, and you cant very well skip ALL of it, but the lectures are a rarity at Yale, and even if you have no particular interest in the subject matter.

I would definitely recommend this course to you! Please take it if you, like I, want to take a good history class or want to understand this discipline more in its entirety. Please, please take it. You will not regret it!
Absolutely  Snyder is one of Yales great lecturers and the material is important and interesting.
Yes. Just take it
Take this class if you're at all interested in learning about 20th century Europe.  It lives up to the expectations and delivers a pretty thorough picture of the region during this time period.
I definitely would. You learn so much.

I would absolutely recommend this course. I walked in the first day and sat in the back of the class because I did not think I would enjoy it, but after 5 minutes of Professor Snyder's lecture I was scribbling down notes as fast as I could. Definitely a must take!
Yes because it is taught by great professor
yes, this was an amazing lecture
Yes, Timothy Snyder is a must

Definitely recommend. Snyders lectures are phenomenalengaging, interesting, informative, even humorous. Sometimes it is hard to follow the exact run of events, but he does a great job discussing broader themes. Guest lectures from Marci Shore were also very good. Even the readings, while heavy, were quite good.
Yes, it is a great history course, Prof Snyder is a great lecturer, the TF's were all good, and the topic is interesting and relevant.

If you enjoy studying history, this is the right class for you. It can, at times, become a little stale with having to memorize facts and dates for the midterm and final, but for most of the semester I was really interested just because Eastern European history was so foreign to me. Also, it's taught in a way that makes you excited about it.

I would highly recommend this course if you want to learn about Eastern Europe and the huge variety of political systems it lived through in the 20th century. Using this knowledge, one can draw huge parallels with that system and modern day Europe.
I would recommend this course. It was incredibly interesting and Professor Snyder is incredible. You get incredible accounts from a professor whos spent his life studying the subject. Awesome class.
Incredibly interesting course taught by quite possibly the best professor at Yale. Grading is fair and workload is manageable. Id highly recommend it for anyone.
Yes. Purely for the lecture and interesting content.
Yes! Must take!

Yes! This class is so interesting, lectures are amazing, Professor Snyder is a great lecturer and super super knowledgeable on the subject, and the class has so much more relevance to our modern world than I ever thought it would. Great class.
Yes! Professor Snyder is amazing and I learned so much.

I would wholeheartedly recommend this course to another student. Professor Snyder is obviously an incredible lecturer, and he captures everyone's attention every single lecture. Really relevant and fascinating course.

I would recommend this course to anyone generally interested in history as a subject, I personally entered with very little background knowledge of Eastern Europe however found that throughout the course not only did my familiarity with the subject grow, but I found myself more and more interested in pursuing history classes in the future. Overall a solid survey class with the appropriate mixture of breadth and depth.
Yes! Amazing soeaker and teacher

Yes, even though the course itself isn't administered very well logistics-wise, taking a class with Tim Snyder is kind of a must for anyone at Yale, even people majoring in completely different fields (like me). Hes a very talented lecturer, and every class is almost a performance, even though its just him talking for 50 minutes with no slides. Skimming the endless readings and going to section is a little annoying, but definitely worth it. Since nobody actually does the readings, the workload for the course is really quite low. And even though lectures cover a lot of material, the midterm and final only really test the main ideas.
I would definitely recommend this course. The material of the course is very engaging and thought-provoking. Additionally, Professor Snyder is great and has a great passion for his class and work.
Excellent.  Waaaaaay better than the first half.
I would recommend this class to any student interested in history
Yes if you want to learn from a leading historian on the topic

I would recommend it, Professor Snyder is a true expert in the field and is an amazing lecturer as well. The material is also fascinating and very relevant to modern day. Overall a great class to explore a topic you may not have looked into before with a professor who makes each class enjoyable.

Eastern Europe is amazing! You go into very great detail about the region and the lectures are very engaging. The reading per week, however, is sometimes simply impossible to complete in the given time and varies a lot (there were weeks that were 150 pages and weeks that were 500+). This forces you to pick and choose which readings you do especially if you are in a reading-intensive major. Also, the professor does not offer the course packet/supplemental readings online--you have to buy it at Tyco for $100+ (the readings don't change year to year so you can pick up a vintage boi on free and for sale if you like for cheaper). Prof. Snyder's books are probably the most worthwhile and interesting readings in the course.

I think every student atYale, whether History major or not, should attend this course. It is so well taught and so essential to our understanding of the modern day world, that it would be a shame not to take it.
